prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Established structural causal models (SCMs), the do-operator, and counterfactual semantics—the baseline formalism that TCMs explicitly generalize.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper frames Topos Causal Models as a strict generalization of Pearl’s SCMs, preserving intervention semantics while relocating them into an elementary topos where truth is Heyting-valued rather than Boolean.

prior_works.title: Causal Theories: A Categorical Perspective
prior_works.role: Introduced a categorical (symmetric monoidal) representation of causal structure and interventions via string diagrams and comonoids.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TCMs extend Fong’s categorical encoding from monoidal categories to toposes, so that causal mechanisms compose via sheaf gluing and interventions are interpreted as subobjects classified internally.

prior_works.title: A Synthetic Approach to Markov Kernels, Conditional Independence, and Theorems on Bayesian Networks
prior_works.role: Developed Markov categories, giving an abstract categorical calculus for stochastic maps, conditional independence, and Bayesian networks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper leverages Fritz’s categorical probabilistic machinery to treat causal mechanisms as morphisms internal to a topos, enabling conditional-independence reasoning without committing to set-based kernels.

prior_works.title: The Sheaf-Theoretic Structure of Non-Locality and Contextuality
prior_works.role: Pioneered using sheaves to glue local data and analyze obstructions to global sections, with an intuitionistic logical viewpoint.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The use of sheaves in TCMs to combine ‘independent mechanisms’ into consistent global behavior parallels Abramsky–Brandenburger’s gluing/obstruction paradigm, repurposed from contextuality to causal compatibility.

prior_works.title: Quantifiers and Sheaves
prior_works.role: Introduced key ideas leading to elementary toposes, subobject classifiers, and internal (intuitionistic) logic via hyperdoctrines.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TCMs rely on the Lawvere–Tierney insight that subobject classifiers endow a topos with Heyting-valued truth, which the paper uses to define interventions and counterfactual predicates as internal subobjects.

prior_works.title: Sheaves in Geometry and Logic: A First Introduction to Topos Theory
prior_works.role: Canonical reference for topos theory, detailing sheaves, subobject classifiers, and the internal Heyting algebra of truth values.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The construction of subobject classifiers and sheaf gluing that underpin TCMs follows directly from Mac Lane–Moerdijk, enabling the non-Boolean internal logic the paper assigns to causal and counterfactual statements.

prior_works.title: A Topos Foundation for Theories of Physics (I–IV)
prior_works.role: Demonstrated operational use of a topos’s internal intuitionistic logic and generalized truth values (via subobject classifiers) in a scientific domain.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing how to conduct reasoning with Heyting-valued truth inside a topos, Döring–Isham provide a template that the paper adapts to causal and counterfactual inference.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution—Topos Causal Models (TCMs)—sits at the intersection of causal inference and categorical/topos-theoretic logic. Pearl’s Causality supplies the baseline semantics of structural causal models, interventions, and counterfactuals that TCMs explicitly generalize. Fong’s categorical perspective on causal theories demonstrates how causal structure and interventions can be handled diagrammatically, a compositional view that TCMs lift from symmetric monoidal settings to full toposes. Fritz’s Markov categories provide an abstract calculus for stochastic maps and conditional independence, informing the paper’s treatment of causal mechanisms as morphisms that can be reasoned about independently of set-based probability. 
Sheaf theory is central to TCMs’ promise of composing “independent mechanisms” into consistent global behavior: Abramsky–Brandenburger’s sheaf-theoretic gluing/obstruction viewpoint directly motivates using sheaves to test global causal compatibility. The topos-theoretic backbone comes from Lawvere’s development of subobject classifiers and internal intuitionistic logic, together with Mac Lane–Moerdijk’s comprehensive account of sheaves, toposes, and Heyting algebras. These works collectively justify the paper’s claim that interventions and counterfactual predicates can be represented as subobjects with Heyting-valued truth. Finally, Döring–Isham’s topos foundation for physics provides a concrete precedent for doing scientific reasoning inside a topos, showing that generalized truth values and internal languages are not merely formal curiosities but workable tools—an approach the present paper adapts to causal and counterfactual inference.
